article.headline: Bigelow, Araujo lead Cougars
article.linkText: Streaking BYU puts Utah in bubble trouble
article.story: PROVO, Utah (AP) -- Brigham Young had plenty of reason to celebrate after its final home game of the season. The Cougars avoided being swept by their biggest rival for the second straight year, clinched the No. 2 seed in the league tournament and won their seventh straight, beating Utah 70-57 Monday night. "This is really gratifying because we're right in the thick of being an NCAA bubble team. We needed this win, so that was the biggest part of it," said Mark Bigelow, who scored 19 points in his final home game. Rafael Araujo, also a senior, had 16 points in his last Marriott Center appearance for BYU (19-7, 9-4), which moved ahead of Utah (20-8, 8-5) in the Mountain West Conference standings. Air Force clinched the MWC regular-season title and the top seed in the tournament earlier Monday with a 62-49 win over San Diego State. Because of tiebreakers, the Cougars will be the No. 2 seed and the Utes No. 3 in the league tournament next week in Denver. Both could still be longshots for the NCAA tournaments. "I don't know," Bigelow said. "We may have to go win that (conference) tournament to get in." Utah already has 20 wins, but can get only 21 during the regular season and may also need a run in the MWC tournament. "We basically had to win the conference tournament anyway. Now we've really got to," said Nick Jacobson, who led Utah with 16 points. Andrew Bogut added 14 points and seven rebounds, but the Australian freshman was just 4-for-14 from the floor as the Cougars outplayed the Utes inside. The Cougars outscored Utah 36-14 inside,shot 53.6 percent (15-for-28) in the second half and forced 23 turnovers. "Turnovers. That was a big part of the story. If you don't get aggressive, on the ball, they can throw it in their post much easier," BYU coach Steve Cleveland said. Even with the 10 p.m. MST starting time, the Marriott Center was packed and loud as 22,718 fans came to see the state's biggest rivalry. BYU blew a 17-point lead in Salt Lake City and Utah won 64-56 Jan. 31. This time, the Cougars let an 11-point lead in the second half fall only to four before regaining control and hanging on for the victory. "We made hustle plays, we created turnovers. We did a much better job on the defensive glass. We got stops when the game was on the line," Cleveland said. BYU pulled ahead 34-23 on an 8-0 run, getting six straight from Araujo. Utah got within four on a 3-pointer by Jacobson and a basket by Bogut, but the Cougars responded with seven straight points to pull away again. Garner Meads' shot from the lane put the Cougars up 50-39. Utah trimmed it to six on a 3-pointer by Bogut, but Kevin Woodberry answered with a 3. BYU led by at least six the rest of the way and continued to widen the margin as Utah attempted some desperation shots. BYU led 26-19 at halftime, using a 19-2 run to pull away at the end of the half. After going scoreless for the first 3:53, the Cougars took advantage of 14 Utah turnovers to take the lead. Mike Hall, who score 21, led BYU on a 10-0 run that he capped with a steal and a two-handed dunk to tie it at 17-all with about six minutes left in the half. Hall scored seven during the rally and Bigelow started it with a 3-pointer. Hall gave the Cougars their first lead on a layup through traffic to put BYU up 21-19. Then after a Utah turnover, Meads slammed in an offensive rebound with about two minutes left in the half. Utah turned the ball over again as the shot clock was winding down and Bigelow added a 3-pointer to put the Cougars up by seven at halftime.
